ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed my speaking, writing, and listening skills.
Increased my ability to communicate and understand spoken Spanish. I gained more confidence with being able to practice my Spanish in both academic and natural settings.
I learned to write, speak and read Spanish very well. I think this course, in combination with Spanish 130, can make you fluent in Spanish.
I received a better grasp of conjugating, enhanced my Spanish speaking capabilities, and learned more about the Hispanic culture.
I learned a lot in this course. My academic Spanish writing improved significantly and I finally feel like I understand the subjunctive.
I felt that my spanish ability was definitely developed by this course and that Najera did a good job teaching

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of this class consisted of the amount of speaking, written assignments , as well as cultural projects. However, learning a language online is not ideal.

The course had a great structure. The examinations and quizzes were well spaced out. The workload was extremely manageable. This course was much less work than Spanish 130. It was great to have chances to talk to other students and the professor on a daily basis. It was a great class to interact with others, especially during remote learning.

Strengths - Professor Luna Njera was a strength. She was super understanding and receptive to feedback, and she always privately direct messaged us when we talked, giving us corrections about conjugations, vocab, grammar, etc. 

Weaknesses: In the beginning, the class was a bit intimidating because the class was very speaking-heavy, but I quickly adjusted to it! Everyone makes mistakes and don't be shy about that. That's part of the learning process!

I thought this course was great. I think it could be improved by slightly reducing the number of materials covered in the final month or so, in order to spend more time on the films and novels, which I loved.
I felt that towards the end of the semester we stopped doing small group activities, which I felt boosted by engagement and retention, so I was a bit bummed to see them go

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was online

The breakout rooms were a very nice chance to meet other students and interact in ways you cannot in other courses. The asynchronous days were great in this course. You reinforced what you learned in class, but the time requirement was incredibly fair. I do not think any of the practices geared toward virtual learning need improvement.
I would say given that most language classes are based on a discussion/seminar format, I didn't have trouble learning or engaging in this course.
Profesora Njera did such a good job keeping everyone engaged on Zoom. I was so impressed.
I think that the student-led discussions about the readings and virtual theater was always very engaging and interesting. I will repeat once again, I would like some more small group work

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I would for a normal semester in person.

My only complaint is about my Spanish placement.

I am a freshman who was placed into Spanish II at the beginning of the semester. I emailed the department to ask if I could retake the exam to hopefully place into Spanish III. I believed that with my prior Spanish education and test scores, my entrance exam did not properly portray what I knew. The Spanish department declined, which I understood because of policy. However, after semester II, I was emailing my Spanish III professor about my upcoming section time, and based on my writing within the email, she requested that I take the exam again. I did so and was placed into Spanish IV.

I would have been happy with any decision made about my placement; however, I do not believe that changing my level mid year was ideal for my Spanish education. Instead, if I would have been able to retake the exam initially, then I might have been able to take Spanish III and then IV.

Other than that, I had a great experience with the class and was able to improve my Spanish.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The workload is very manageable, and all of the work you do feels very valuable. If you take the course seriously, you can emerge feeling fluent enough to speak to others in Spanish. Also, the professor was great and kind at all times. The cultural project presentation was the most fun assignment I have had at Yale. The classes themselves are very unique in that you have a chance to really converse with others in the class. This is something very unique to Spanish in my time at Yale. This class is very enjoyable and fair in grading and workload.
Yes! Spanish 140 was more engaging, fun, and interesting than Spanish 130. For a 1.5 credit class, the workload wasn't too bad.
Yes, I would. It was by far the best foreign language instruction Ive ever received.
I would recommend this level and also najera

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were readings and small movies to watch outside of class.
The class was only a virtual discussion format based class.
The homework had some virtual lab elements sometimes
It was a virtual seminar
